title: In its January 2021 World Economic Outlook report, by how much will the International Monetary Fund (IMF) estimate the global economy grew in 2020?
preds: World GDP shrunk by about 6% in 2020
Changing forecast due to passage of time.
Don't mind me, just dropping in for the free points Their October forecast for all 2020 was -4.9%, I mean...
At this point of the year GDP forecasts are already fairly accurate and it is easy to see that the world gdp cannot be increasing in 2020.

With technology being able to absorb quite a bit of the widespread shutdowns due to COVID-19 and being able to work remotely, I believe that the economy is a bit more robust than anticipated with various national banks being accommodative through low-interest rates and stimulus measure.
Recently released report says -4.4% this year

Agathe Demarais, The Economist Intelligence Unit's global forecasting director: "Latest IMF forecasts have pencilled in 4.4% contraction for global economy this year - this might still be too optimistic, as households are saving instead of consuming across developed world." https://twitter.com/AgatheDemarais/status/1316740620921102339

IMF's October World Economic Outlook, out today: "In our latest World Economic Outlook, we continue to project a deep recession in 2020. Global growth is projected to be -4.4 percent, an upward revision of 0.8 percent compared to our June update. This upgrade owes to somewhat less dire outcomes in the second quarter, as well as signs of a stronger recovery in the third quarter, offset partly by downgrades in some emerging and developing economies." https://blogs.imf.org/2020/10/13/a-long-uneven-and-uncertain-ascent/

IMF projected -4.9 in June.  The Economist reports Calculations by Goldman Sachs, a bank, suggest that social-distancing measures continue to reduce global gdp by 7-8%—roughly in line with what The Economist argued in April, when we coined the term “90% economy” to describe what would happen once lockdowns began to be lifted.  7% below the +3.5% original estimates for 2020 put the number at -3.5% and -4.5% https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/WEO/Issues/2020/06/24/WEOUpdateJune2020 https://www.google.com/amp/s/amp.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2020/09/16/is-the-world-economy-recovering
Putting more confidence in less than 1.5% based on links provided by others here.

The OECD September Economic Outlook interim report projects global growth of -4.5% in 2020 [1]. This is fairly close to the IMF's June Economic Outlook update projecting global growth of -4.9% [2].  The IMF's next economic outlook update should be out sometime in the next few weeks. [1] https://read.oecd-ilibrary.org/economics/oecd-economic-outlook/volume-2020/issue-1_34ffc900-en#page2
[2] https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/WEO
Increasing my very low probabilities a little bit, because I realize I'm not really that well calibrated for low percentages.

The managing director and the chief economist of the IMF on what is needed to recover from the Great Lockdown recession:  
"Securing a sustained recovery and emerging stronger from the Great Lockdown will require action on three fronts: First, the health crisis must be brought to an end—durably and everywhere. Impressive advances in vaccine development raise hopes that this objective can be achieved. Second, people need to be able to find productive jobs. This requires preventing excessive firm bankruptcies and creating an environment for job-rich growth. Finally, our future must be more sustainable and inclusive than our past. This requires policies to arrest global warming and reverse rising inequality." [1] Latest IMF global economic outlook (from June): "Global growth is projected at –4.9 percent in 2020, 1.9 percentage points below the April 2020 World Economic Outlook (WEO) forecast." [2] [1] https://foreignpolicy.com/2020/09/09/great-lockdown-economy-recovery-coronavirus/
[2] https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/WEO
It is virtually impossible to have any positive growth in 2020, and eventually even in 2021. Forecasts indicate a potential contraction of 4%-5% of the world's GDP this year.

Was originally too optimistic. Looking at historical the last recession was negative for the year of 2009 but positive for 2008 despite one quarter of recession in the US. We've had one quarter of significant negative GDP growth. Quarters 3 and 4 may still be down year over year. This is all US numbers and other places may have better growth numbers on average, which is the primary reason for uncertainty. Will have to update after third quarter GDP numbers come out. https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/WEO/Issues/2016/12/31/A-Policy-Driven-Multispeed-Recovery
Consider we are on track for almost -5% growth...
US, Europe, China, India etc. all far behind even reaching zero.
Economic effects of pandemic mostly underestimated so far; also countries with good Covid19 situation affected by global challenges

The onset of the Coronavirus pandemic has resulted in a severe contraction of the rate of growth as predicted by the IMF, EU, US and others.
Covid-19 attacked both the advanced, emerging and lagging economies at different rates and times that have resulted in an uneven degree and severity of lockdowns throughout the world. There has been a deliberate effort by the advanced economies to ease the severity of the lockdowns to conserve and revive economic life of their societies.
Various reports have indicated a sharp or ‘V’ shape recoveries that would produce a rapid bounce back of economies and optimistically suggest a return to growth rates.
However, the month of August has seen spikes in infection rates in some areas as a result of easing of lockdown restrictions or an ignoring of them by the general public.
This before a recognition of the passing of the first wave. In the 1918-1920 flu pandemic there were four waves of the infection before it ran out of steam, with very similar lockdown restrictions in place.
It is quite conceivable that the Covid-19 pandemic will be affecting economies  for the next 12-18 months (vaccine dependent). 
Therefore, I propose the World Economic growth rates to be negative for 2020. https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/WEO/Issues/2020/06/24/WEOUpdateJune2020  https://www.cnet.com/personal-finance/coronavirus-recession-how-bad-it-could-get-and-what-it-means-for-you/  https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/ip_20_1269  https://www.spglobal.com/ratings/en/research-insights/topics/economic-reports-july-2020
The affect of covid shrinking most developed economies in Q1/2 and likely Q3 means low growth should be expected

As of June 2020, the IMF World Economic Outlook Update has revised its global growth projection downwards again and is projected to be negative. Solidifying my prediction in light of this information.
IMF has lowered their prediction from -3% to -4.9% growth in 2020. I don't like assigning 100% but it seems warranted in these circumstances. https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/WEO
Update for passing time. Reducing time spent for forecasting for a while.
Well Coronavirus has made the lower end even more likely than I originally thought.  Moving from 70% <1.5% to 99%.  Just find it hard to say 100pc to anything!

With current World projection at -3.00% the ranges seem to be off. Virtually impossible now to be above 1.5%

IMF's June 2020 World Economic Outlook: "Global growth is projected at –4.9 percent in 2020, 1.9 percentage points below the April 2020 World Economic Outlook (WEO) forecast. The COVID-19 pandemic has had a more negative impact on activity in the first half of 2020 than anticipated, and the recovery is projected to be more gradual than previously forecast." https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/WEO/Issues/2020/06/24/WEOUpdateJune2020

Covid cases are taking off in developing nations (1) and are likely to get worse before they get better. Many developed nations have already provided immense fiscal and monetary stimulus and in some cases numbers are climbing (USA) or for a resurgence in cases as economies open up (2). Combine this information with the 25th of June statement by the IMF stating a decline of 5% in economic activity for 2020. A two percent decrease from their statement in April 2020 (3). I could easily see a further decline in economic outlook as the year progresses and the devastation becomes more apparent to people. They have even downgraded their GDP outlook for 2021 (ibid). IMF has readjusted its projected world growth to -3% for 2020. 2009 saw the world economy shrink by 1.7% and that crisis wasn't as deep as this one. I'm quite certain the threat of the virus will still be here in the autumn, either by it never going away or by a second wave, which will hamper growth badly. Even if the virus "disappears" in the summer, the number of companies going out of business and the number of people getting unemployed at the moment makes a shrinkage of the economy this year all but certain.
IMF is a pessimistic approach in the global economic growth forecast.     https://www.imf.org/~/media/Files/Publications/WEO/2020/April/English/ch2.ashx?la=en
The IMF has been pretty open about the fact that the global economy will contract in 2020.

Reaffirming my forecast, especially in light of reports of 40% drop in GDP in Q2.

With already one month of economic activity in manufacturing and serves disrupted due to lock-down and the consequences of staggered easing of the lock-down, it is estimated that at least one quarter of the global economic activity is wiped out. Hence the entire global output of nearly USD 3 Trillion is wiped. 
This means that there is no room for growth at all in the pessimistic scenario and in the optimistic scenario of complete recovery in the next half financial year, the growth will be sufficient to match the losses.
COVID-19 will suppress global economic growth.

https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/WEO The International Monetary Fund projected global economic growth to rise from an estimated 2.9 percent in 2019 to 3.3 percent in 2020 and 3.4 percent for 2021. However, due to the worldwide outbreak of the COVID-19 virus, the global economy has done a complete turnaround. Mass unemployment and a sharp decline in the stock market have now made it seem almost impossible that there will be any economic outcome this year aside from a recession. Unless there is substantial growth in the third and fourth financial quarters of 2020 (which is now largey unexpected), it is highly unlikely that the International Monetary Fund will estimate global economic growth at anything above 1.5%.
Goldman Sachs economist revising down 2020 global growth forecast from 1.25% last week to  -1% this week.

The International Monetary Fund projected global economic growth to rise from an estimated 2.9 percent in 2019 to 3.3 percent in 2020 and 3.4 percent for 2021. 
Since the activities to contain the spread of the virus are affecting the global economy, in given that the US stock market has dropped into bear market territory (i.e. more than 20% down from its peak), it is hard to imagine that we are not moving towards a global recession, given that many EU countries were already starting to contract (like Germany and Italy) even before this virus shock. This verdict is based on past historical patterns, where sharp stock market decline precedes economic recessions. Trump's unilateral approach to a global problem is typical Trump, but we have people in Congress with more sensible policy approaches who will continue to ignore him and also sensible policy makers at the state and local level. 
As the World Economic Forum typically leans toward more conservative estimates, the coronavirus crisis would further act as a big shock to the economy, due to unprecedented amounts of unemployment and other demand shocks. A severe pandemic can result in millions of deaths, and even the most conservative estimates suggest that pandemics destroy up to 1% of global GDP, which is comparable to other top-priority threats, such as climate change (World Bank). 
The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said global growth could plummet to just 1.5 percent in 2020, far less than the 3 percent it projected before the virus surfaced. Additionally, central bankers have less room to loosen monetary policy today than they did heading into the 2007 recession. In the United States, the federal funds rate was above 5 percent back then and was ultimately lowered to near zero. 
“Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley economists joined the rush on Wall Street to declare that the coronavirus has triggered a global recession, with the debate now focusing on its likely length and depth. A day after President Donald Trump conceded the U.S. slump alone is set to be “a bad one,” economists threw away their forecasts that the world could avoid tumbling into recession for the first time since the financial crisis.” S&P Global added in a report expecting that growth would range 1% to 1.5%.
“The hit to consumer spending and business investment, plus the oil price damage to energy infrastructure investment likely means a 1% contraction in first quarter and 6% contraction in the second, U.S. Chief Economist Beth Ann Bovino said in a note.” https://www.ft.com/content/1056a4da-6acd-11ea-800d-da70cff6e4d3

The WEO tends to be more conservative in their estimates, tending towards a status quo. Recently in 2018 and 2019, they have been underestimating global slowdown due to weakening demand by -0.2(Jan18 est.: 3.9% vs Jan19 actual: 3.7%) and -0.6(Jan19 est.: 3.5% vs Jan20 actual: 2.9%) respectively.
-> Because of this, I would conservatively cut their base 3.3% forecast to 3% based on consistent overestimation alone. The coronavirus crisis would further act as a big shock to the economy, due to unprecedented amount of unemployment and other demand shocks.
- OECD mentioned that even in its best case scenario with few cases outside China, it would cut its growth forecast by 0.5%. In worst case, it would consider cutting 1.5% -> bringing us to the 1.5% edge. Source: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/02/business/economy/global-economy-coronavirus.html
- At the same time, multiple central banks including Bank of Japan, European Central Bank and Bank of England issued press statements that they are ready to help. This could be a stabilising force. Multiple governments have also prepared stimulus packages.
- Considering balance of supply shock and demand shock caused by Covid-19, I'm leaning towards the view that the world economy currently is too fragile to recover quickly even after the health crisis fades. https://www.moneyandbanking.com/commentary/2020/3/8/covid-19-what-can-monetary-policy-do-3

Things are mostly likely to be negative.  But depending on how things could go there could be a small chance of a massive bounce at year end to counteract the first part of the year.  When depends on the length of time the pandemic takes to evolve and how much it changes people’s behaviour.

"Global growth is projected to rise from an estimated 2.9 percent in 2019 to 3.3 percent in 2020 and 3.4 percent for 2021—a downward revision of 0.1 percentage point for 2019 and 2020 and 0.2 for 2021 compared to those in the October World Economic Outlook (WEO). The downward revision primarily reflects negative surprises to economic activity in a few emerging market economies, notably India, which led to a reassessment of growth prospects over the next two years. In a few cases, this reassessment also reflects the impact of increased social unrest."

To go less than 1,5% there'd need to be more alarming things to happen first. Between 1,5 - 2 seems fairly possible, but still not great until more signs of low economic growth comes to light. 2,1 - 2,6% seems possible, as it's highest value is only 0,9 less than the prediction given in January and it's values cover 0,5% change. 2,7 - 3% seems reasonably possible too, but as the values cover only 0,3% it's less likely than the previous one in a situation where the economy is coming down. To get more than 3% at this stage, there should be strong indicators later half of the year that would in cover also the losses in economy of the first half of the year, which seems unlikely at this point.

The size of the effect of COVID-19 on economic activity will be the determining factor on global growth this year. While it might be true that China and other in east Asia may be starting to contain the virus, the effects on economic activity will continue for most of this year as there is suppressed demand, defered investment and restictions on the movements of people. Tourism will remain highly impacted for all of 2020. We have yet to see the full impact of the virus on the US and Europe - unless this turns out to be very limited, I can't see less than and 1%-1.7% impact on global growth and possibly more.

January 2019 WEO forecast for 2020 real growth was 3.3%

Prior proba of GDP<1.5% = 5% Impact of Covid-19  
On march 2nd OECD projected Covid-19 would cut global growth from 2.9% to 2.4%. This was prior Italy lock-down (March-9th) . Number of new cases /day is increasing rapidly Europe and the US, but is now close to zero in China, indicating that the virus can be contained in 3 months. How long will the travel bans and other measures needed to contain the virus will remain in place and slow growth? it could be another 3  to 6 months.
Then the world economy went through a long period of expansion, growth around 3.5% since 2010, covid-19 could be the catalyst for an end of business cycle slow-down.   Overall, I haircut OECD's number by another 50bps, to get my expected total growth:1.9, so more than 50% chance of GDP growth below 2% inclusive say 55%. 
Then split this proba in two 35% chance less 1.5% and 20% chance between 1.5% and 2%

Baseline: probability distribution of global growth in last 40 years (roughly, from World Bank): 8%/14%/13%/15%/50% Adjustments:
1) Business cycle: skew to lower growth due to late cycle. 18%/20%/15%/12%/35%
2) Covid-19: skew to lower growth. If classified as a pandemic, it could lead to a 1% GDP growth impact (https://www.worldbank.org/en/topic/pandemics). 30%/25%/22%/15%/8%.
3) Policy intervention: Limited monetary response capacity. Fiscal could be higher but consensus is on restraint, so unlikely to change significantly. Adjusting probability of lower growth scenarios, higher central scenarios. 25%/29%/23%/15%/8%
4) Not taking into account other factors (yet)

OECD March 2 is estimating 2.4% growth down 0.5pp from initial  2.9% est. This assumes a base case containment and China having a end Q1 trough, but relative containment outside China. Also consider trade issues, small business disruption and capital market volatility.    A broader contagion scenario brings growth down to 1.4% So, China is troughing but March looks early. More like Q2.   But US has/is underperforming on its COVID response. Even is EU - maybe - is performing OK.  This means we are going to be closer to the broader contagion scenario, with down side risk.  The point estimate for that is 1.4%  or right in the 1.5 boundary.  I don't think the containment scenario is now correct, so only give it 5% weight, but it is possible. The US might mobilise.  The other two downside scenarios are both quite likely, but I'm pessimistic on US which is the major economy by some margin. That could change as time evolves.
